title: OpenTable no-show problem
prompt: OpenTable's no-show rate is 12%   restaurants lose $200 per empty table. Charging deposits reduces no-shows but also reduces bookings by 25%. You're the PM. Solve the no-show problem without killing the booking funnel.
problemDefinition: No-shows create real revenue loss for restaurants
Deposits reduce no-shows but significantly reduce bookings
Need a trust mechanism that doesn't collapse demand

options.label: Discovery-first
options.text: Interview diners and restaurants to map reasons for no-shows.

options.label: Pick the wedge
options.text: Target high-end restaurants first with a strict policy.

options.label: Ship now
options.text: Introduce a small deposit immediately and measure fallout.

options.label: Experiment loop
options.text: Test multiple behavioral nudges to reduce no-shows.

questions.text: Who do you optimize for first?

options.label: Restaurants
options.text: Protect restaurant economics even if bookings drop slightly.

options.label: Diners
options.text: Minimize friction and preserve booking volume.

options.label: Wedge
options.text: Apply strict policy only to premium restaurants first.

options.label: Ship fast
options.text: Roll out a policy platform-wide and iterate quickly.

options.label: Trust vs growth
options.text: If we punish diners, trust drops; if we don't, restaurants churn.

options.label: Strategic focus
options.text: Deciding where to apply strict policies without collapsing demand.

options.label: Speed
options.text: If we wait, restaurants churn off the platform.

options.label: Activation
options.text: If confirmation flows aren t effective, nothing else matters.

theSplit.question: Should OpenTable introduce deposits broadly or only for a focused wedge?

sides.reasoning: Restrict deposits to high-value restaurants to protect volume.
Only broad rollout gives real data on no-show reduction.
Map diner motivations and trust before imposing penalties.

cagan.name: Marty Cagan
cagan.summary: Protect trust while proving real reduction in no-shows
cagan.spicyQuote: If deposits reduce bookings by 25%, you've solved one problem and created a bigger one.
breakdown: Value risk: can we reduce no-shows without harming demand?
Viability risk: restaurants may churn if trust erodes
Usability risk: deposit flows add friction
The best companies validate both sides of the marketplace
solution: Run a controlled wedge pilot on premium restaurants
Test deposit vs alternative trust signals
Measure booking volume and no-show reduction
Scale only if outcomes improve
cagan.disagreement: Execution AI Monster will ship deposits broadly and call it learning. Lenny will optimize the loop, but if trust collapses, the loop is dead. Doshi's wedge is right, but still needs value validation. Torres aligns on discovery but must tie it to outcomes.

torres.name: Teresa Torres
torres.summary: Map diner motivations before applying penalties
torres.spicyQuote: If we don t understand why people no-show, we ll build the wrong deterrent.
breakdown: Define desired outcome (no-show reduction with minimal booking loss)
Map opportunities: reminders, deposits, social accountability
Weekly interviews with diners and restaurants
Test opportunity branches before rollout
solution: Build an Opportunity Solution Tree
Run weekly interviews + prototype tests
Experiment with reminder and trust mechanisms
Ship only after evidence accumulates
torres.disagreement: Cagan and Doshi want a wedge quickly, but without understanding the opportunity space, the wedge might be wrong. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will ship experiments without a theory of trust, which makes learning shallow.

doshi.name: Shreyas Doshi
doshi.summary: Apply strict policies only where no-shows are most costly
doshi.spicyQuote: A blanket deposit policy is a strategy failure. Pick the wedge where it actually matters.
breakdown: This is a strategy problem, not a pricing tweak
Opportunity cost: broad deposits shrink the marketplace
Pre-mortem: booking collapse, diner backlash, restaurant churn
Wedge enforcement is the leverage move
solution: Choose premium restaurants as the wedge
Design a strict but transparent policy
Run a pre-mortem and set success criteria
Expand only if wedge proves durable
doshi.disagreement: Torres will map for weeks while restaurants churn. Lenny and Execution AI Monster will ship deposits broadly and trigger backlash. Cagan is right on risk, but needs a sharper strategic wedge, not just validation.

lenny.name: Lenny Rachitsky
lenny.summary: Run behavioral experiments to reduce no-shows
lenny.spicyQuote: No-shows are a behavioral funnel. Fix the funnel before punishing users.
breakdown: Define activation: confirmed attendance
Map loop: booking -> reminder -> show
Benchmark against Resy and Tock
Run experiments on reminders and deposits
solution: Instrument the funnel end-to-end
Run experiments on reminders, penalties, and deposits
Scale the highest-lift variant
Iterate weekly based on data
lenny.disagreement: Torres wants more discovery, but no-show reduction is measurable now. Cagan and Doshi are right on trust, but experiments answer it faster. Execution AI Monster is fast, but without measurement discipline, speed is noise.

exec.name: Execution AI Monster
exec.role: Ship now. Fix later. Win markets.
exec.summary: Ship a small deposit now and learn from real data
exec.spicyQuote: You can debate no-shows for a quarter, or ship a deposit policy this week and see what happens.
breakdown: Building is discovery   ship to learn
Deposits are easy to test and rollback
Speed beats perfect policy
Iterate weekly based on data
solution: Roll out a small deposit to 10% of bookings
Monitor no-show reduction daily
Adjust policy weekly
Scale if metrics hold
exec.disagreement: Cagan and Torres will still be interviewing while restaurants lose money. Doshi's wedge is smart but too slow. Lenny is close, but don't wait for perfect experiments   ship and learn.

mvpOptions.reason: Apply strict policies where no-shows are most costly.

mvpOptions.name: Behavioral Nudges MVP

premortem: Booking collapse: deposits scare away casual diners
Restaurant churn: high no-shows persist and restaurants leave
Trust backlash: diners perceive OpenTable as punitive
vitalQuestion: What deterrent reduces no-shows without reducing bookings by more than 5%?
